text:
A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer diet
- Pioneer schools
- Pioneer churches
- Pioneer recreation and social life
- Pioneer farming experiences
- Folklore in Saskatchewan
- Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

[Stamp: RECEIVED JUN 6 1955]
PIONEER EXPERIENCES

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as any other. Some of the questions have will not apply to your experience and may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry if a number of them seem strange. Just extra sheet of paper to answer, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914 and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please save the ones you would be willing to answer.

| ALL questionnaires |
|-------------------|
| Pioneer life     |
| Pioneer schools   |
| Pioneer recreation and social life |
| Pioneer farming experiences |
| Pioneers in Saskatchewan |
| Pioneer health and housing |

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: JANZEN, PETER S.

2. Your address: ROSTHERN, #4, SASKATCHEWAN

3. Date: MAY 24, 1955

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country).
   PROVINCE - SKATRINORLOV
   COUNTRY - RUSSIA
   VILLAGE - GREENFIELD

5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   JANZEN, JACOB P. FARMER

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year).
   APRIL 16, 1894

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
   ARRIVED IN MANITOBA JUNE 1893, LIVED HERE TILL MOVED TO SASKATCHEWAN

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc).
   AGE AT ARRIVAL - 9 YEARS

9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   LAND IN RUSSIA WAS SCARCE, AND I WAS FROM A LARGE FAMILY.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?).
    THROUGH GERMAN ADVERTISING MAGAZINES AND CANADIAN LAND AGENTS (MR. KLAS PETERS)
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: JANZEN, PETER J.
2. Your address: ROSEMONT, SK, SASKATCHEWAN
3. Date: MAY 24, 1955
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)
   JANZEN - GREENFIELD VILLAGE - GREENFIELD COUNTY - RUSSIA
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   JANZEN, JACOB P. FARMER
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year).
   ARRIVED, 1894
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
   ARRIVED IN MANITOBA, JUNE, 1893. LIVED HERE THEN MOVED TO SASKATCHEWAN
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a child" or "I was in my teens", etc).
   AGE AT ARRIVAL - 9 YEARS
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   LAND IN RUSSIA WAS SCARCE, AND I WAS FROM A LARGE FAMILY.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information? Through German advertising magazines and Canadian land agents (Mr. Klas Peters))
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   One letter to the family stated "You will come back to Russia yet—Canada is too bad."

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
    With relatives and many friends.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
    Ship, train

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
    On crossing the C.N.R. bridge at Saskatoon, we saw one lone shack where the city now stands.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
    On arriving at Rosserm we spent the first night in the train. The next night we spent with one of the earlier settlers.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? Father had a homestead on the SW¼ S2 T+3 R+4 Wof3: 6 miles west of Rosserm.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
    None. Lived on Father's homestead all my life.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?
    Father made his living with farming before and after he came west.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to West?

One letter to the family stated "you will come back to Russia yet—Canada is too bad."

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?

With relatives and my own friends.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Ship, train

14. What incidents of the journey west do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

On crossing the C.N.R. bridge at Saskatoon, we saw one lone shack where the site now stands.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

On arriving at Moose Jaw we spent the first night in the train. The next night we spent with one of the earlier settlers.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? Father had a homestead on the S.W. ¼ S.2 T.43 R.4 W of 3½ 6 miles west of Regina.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

None. Lived on father's homestead all my life.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Father made his living with farming before and after he came west.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   One letter to the family stated "You will come back to Russia yet—Canada is too bad."

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   With relatives and many friends.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   Ship, train

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
   On crossing the C.N.R. bridge at Saskatoon, we saw one lone shack where the city now stands.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   On arriving at Rosthern we spent the first night in the train. The next night we spent with one of the earlier settlers.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   Father had a homestead on the S.W. ¼ S2 T43 R4 W of 3: 6 miles west of Rosthern.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
   None. Lived on Father's homestead all my life.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?
   Father made his living with farming before and after he came west.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to North America?

One letter to the family stated: "You will come back to Russia yet—Canada is too bad."

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

With relatives and many friends.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Ship, train

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

On crossing the C.N.R. Bridge at Salvation, we saw our lone shack where the city now stands.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

On arriving at Rosthern we spent the first night in the train. The next night we spent with one of the earlier settlers.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Father had a homestead on the S.W. by S2 T+3 R+3 W+3 or 3.6 miles west of Rosthern.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

None. Lived on Father's homestead all my life.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Father made his living with farming before and after he came west.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   In the first years the parents wrote often. I never wrote except once when I sent inheritance money to a sister there.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.
   Married twice. First to Katharina Janzen on April 20, 1907. Second to Maria Martens on November 23, 1911.
   Both weddings took place in Eignenhein church.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?
   No, not through me, but through agents and newspapers.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.
   Some came just previous to our arrival and took up land at Rosthern.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
   Since there were no fences I had to herd the cattle. This was very unpleasant, especially when the mosquitoes were so severe.
   Prairie fires are fresh in my memory. Twice a year one could expect them; fear and panic spread over the colonists as the fire roared across the plains with a sweeping wind.
   Sod houses were quite amusing to me when I first got here.
   The first winter we went to school with one ox. The roads were in no definite order, leading over any property and curving from farm to farm.
   Wheat usually froze before harvest.
   I also remember hearing the shots when "Mighty Voice" was shot by the law.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
   Regular trips were made to town once a week to do the shopping.
   My father had horses but most of the neighbors had only oxen. The longest trips were to Rosthern or Duck Lake on business; 8 and 20 miles.
   Even to church most people went with oxen.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

In the first years our parents wrote often. I never wrote except once when I sent money to a sister there.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? If so, where did they settle?

No, not through me, but through others and new papers.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell them they came and where they settled.

23. In any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

Since there were no fences I had to herd the cattle. This was very unpleasant, especially when the mosquitoes were so severe. Prairie fires are fresh in my memory. Twice again our house could expect them, fear and panic spread over the colonies as the fire rushed across the plains with a sweeping wind.

Sod houses were quite amusing to me when I first got here. The first winter we went to school with one of the boys who were in no better order, eating over any fireplaces and cursing from farm to farm. Wheat usually froze before harvest.

I also remember hearing the stories about "Mary's house" built by the A.B.A.S.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.)

25. How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Regular trips were made to town once a week to do the shopping. My father had horses but most of the neighbors had only oxen. The longest trip were to Rosthern or Dark Lake on business; 8 and 20 miles even to church many people went with oxen.
25. When was the first car used in the community? 1915. By 1917 cars were quite common.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
   NO CAR

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   ROSTHERN, 6 MILES

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   MOST TRADING WAS DONE IN ROSTHERN. DURING THE BATTLE AT DUCK LAKE PRODUCTS WERE TAKEN THERE. SASKATOON LATER WAS FREQUENTLY VISITED.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   ONCE A WEEK ON MAIL DAY

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   I DO NOT KNOW.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   1904 A GROUP OF YOUNG BOYS MADE AN ORDER. GLOVES, SUSPENDERS, COMBS, MIRRORS MADE UP THIS FIRST ORDER.
   1912 REGULAR BUYING BEGAN.
   IT IS HARD TO SAY WHAT FRACTION OF TOTAL PURCHASE WAS FROM CATALOGUES.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   1911 A PRIVATE COMPANY WAS FORMED, "ROSTHERN TELEPHONE COMPANY".
   EACH SHARE FOR $150 WERE BOUGHT BY A TOTAL OF SIX MEMBERS.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   WE HAD COME TO STAY SINCE THERE WAS ENOUGH MONEY FOR THE TRIP TO CANADA ONLY. IN FACT IT NEVER ENTERED OUR MINDS THAT WE WOULD EVEN LIKE TO RETURN, EVEN IF THERE WAS DRAUGHT, HAIL AND HOPPERS.
25. When was the first car used in the community? 1915.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)

29. How often did you shop in the early days?

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues?

What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

1904 A GROUP OF YOUNG BOYS MADE AN ORDER. GLOVES, SUSPENDERS.

1912 HELEN BURKE'S NAME IN THIS LIST APPEARS.

IT IS HARD TO SAY WHAT FRACTION OF TOTAL PURCHASE WAS FROM CATALOGUES.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

WE HAD COME TO STAY SINCE THERE WAS ENOUGH MONEY FOR THE TRIP TO CANADA ONLY. IN FACT IT NEVER ENTERED OUR MINDS THAT WE WOULD EVER LIKE TO RETURN, EVEN IF THERE WAS DRAUGHT, HAIL AND HOPDROPS.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?
Yes some did, but we were soon back again, on their old homestead. The reason for moving was that the first years were bad for frost, and making a start was hard.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?
Many went to B.C. and Ontario, but none have returned.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.
I was Secretary in Church for ten years, and Boss for 20 years. 12 years as Chairman on the Eizenheim School Board, Sunday School Teacher for over 40 years, have also served as Salesman for the Co-op.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)
We were first to start dairying in the district. And to this day we still run a dairy.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).
I do not know the origin of any names. Our school district, Eizenheim, took on a German name because we were a German settlement.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1947? What reasons did they have for moving?

Yes, some did, but they soon came back again, so their old homes were not the reason for moving. The first years were hard.

35. Did many people come away during the 1950s? Did many return?

Many went to Butte and Montana, but none have returned.

36. If you or any member of your family have held public offices or been elected, I was Secretary in [name of town] for two weeks, Road 19-055 for 30 years.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were willing to have or do something in the district, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

For example, selling the first automobile, combining, organizing the first lodge, etc.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, villages, military stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give (1) name and occupation of person responsible for place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of the acquisition (4) any changes in name since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new names as above in (1), (2), (3).

I do not know the origin of any names. Our school district, however, took its name because we were a German settlement.
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (describe).

THRASHING - Picture

AN EARLY FERRY ON THE South SASKATCHEWAN - Picture

Both these pictures are in my possession and are available for copy.

Would you or the person who owns them either

(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?

(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon?

........ (indicate your preference, if any) ..................

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

GRANDCHILDREN - 26

CHILDREN - 10

- P.P. JANZEN - ROSTHERN (FARMER)
- J.D. JANZEN - ROSTHERN (FARMER)
- W.H. JANZEN - ROSTHERN (FARMER)
- MRS. WALTER EPP - LORD (FARMER)
- MRS. OTTO EPP - DRANE (FARMER)
- MRS. HERMAN KLASSEN - GENBUSH (FARMER)
- MRS. EDGAR KLASSEN - GENBUSH (FARMER)

MISS SUSIE JANZEN - ROSTHERN (AT HOME)
MRS. PETER FUNK - DRANE (FARMER)
MRS. JAKE NEUFELD - DUNDEE (FARMER)

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

The greatest improvements have taken place in farming methods and living conditions - food, clothing, travel, houses.

Farming has taken great strides - from ox to horse to steam to tractor. One man today can do four times as much work as one man in the horse age. Even the 16 horse team is no match for our modern machines.

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.

J.J. EPP, LAIRD
John Andres, ROSTHERN

If someone else has filled in this questionnaire for you, please have this person give name and address here:

K.J. DRIEDGER, Box 185, ROSTHERN
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, old photographs, written records/records and reminiscences (describe)? 

THRESHING — PICTURES

THE EARLY FERRY ON THE SOUTH SASKATCHEWAN — PICTURE

Both these pictures are in my possession. No DARE AVAILABLE FOR COPY

Would you or the person who owns them either:
(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying? Yes...
(2) be willing to present them to the Archive Division of the Legislative Library? (again), or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon?

........... (indicate your preference, if any) ........................

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

GRANDCHILDREN — 10
CHILDREN — 7

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came here?

THE GREAT FARM IMPROVEMENTS — FOOD, CLOTHING, TRAVEL, PLEASE

FARMING HAS TAKEN GREAT STRIDES — EVEN ON TO HOUSE TO STEPS TO TRAIN,

ONE MAN TODAY CAN DO FOUR TIMES AS MUCH WORK AS ONE MAN IN THE

HORSE AGE. EVEN THE NO HORSE TEAM IS NO MATCH FOR OUR MODERN

MACHINES.

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this question.

J.J. EPP, LAIRD
John Andres, Roystheden

If someone else has filled in this questionnaire for you, please have this person give name and address below:

K.J. DRIVE EDGER, Box 123, Roystheden
Oxford.

No. 613 S

If Slimtrim Fasteners are to be included, please specify.
Spécifiez si vous voulez des agrafes Slimtrim.

Mississauga, Ontario L5T 1M8
